wall-push-ups.name: Wall Push-Ups
cues: Stand arm's length from a wall.
Place palms flat against the wall at shoulder height.
Lean forward and push back, keeping body straight.
Great for absolute beginners.

knee-push-ups.name: Knee Push-Ups
cues: Perform push-ups from your knees instead of your toes.
Keep a straight line from your head to your knees.
Lower your chest toward the floor.
This reduces the amount of bodyweight you're pushing.

incline-push-ups.name: Incline Push-Ups
cues: Place hands on a bench or elevated surface.
The higher the surface, the easier the exercise.
Maintain a straight body line.
Focus on full range of motion.

push-ups.name: Push-Ups
cues: Hands shoulder-width apart, fingers pointing forward.
Body in a straight line from head to heels.
Lower your chest to the floor, keeping elbows at a 45-degree angle.
Press through your palms to return to the start.

decline-push-ups.name: Decline Push-Ups
cues: Place feet on a bench or elevated surface.
This increases the load on your upper chest and shoulders.
Keep your core tight to prevent your back from sagging.
Control the movement throughout.

diamond-push-ups.name: Diamond Push-Ups
cues: Place your hands close together, forming a diamond shape with thumbs and index fingers.
Keep your elbows close to your body as you lower down.
This significantly increases tricep activation.
Maintain a straight body line throughout.

one-arm-push-ups.name: One-Arm Push-Ups
cues: Place one hand behind your back or on your hip.
Spread your feet wider for stability.
Lower yourself with control using only one arm.
This is an advanced exercise requiring significant strength.

box-squats.name: Box Squats
cues: Place a box or chair behind you.
Squat down until you gently touch the box.
Pause for a second, then stand back up.
This helps control depth and build confidence.

bodyweight-squats.name: Bodyweight Squats
cues: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly out.
Keep your chest up and core engaged.
Push your hips back and bend your knees as if sitting in a chair.
Go down until thighs are at least parallel to the floor.
Drive through your heels to stand back up.

jump-squats.name: Jump Squats
cues: Perform a regular squat, then explode upward into a jump.
Land softly on the balls of your feet.
Immediately absorb the impact and go into the next rep.
Use your arms for momentum.

goblet-squats.name: Goblet Squats
cues: Hold a dumbbell by one end at chest level.
Keep your elbows tucked in.
Squat down, keeping your chest up and back straight.
The weight in front helps you maintain an upright posture.
Drive through your heels to stand up.

pistol-squats.name: Pistol Squats
cues: Balance on one leg, extending the other leg forward.
Lower yourself into a full squat on the standing leg.
Keep your heel on the ground and chest up.
Drive through your heel to return to the standing position.

dead-hang.name: Dead Hang
cues: Hang from the bar with arms fully extended.
Keep shoulders engaged, don't let them collapse.
Hold for time, building up grip strength.
Essential foundation for all pulling exercises.

scapular-pulls.name: Scapular Pulls
cues: Hang from the bar with arms extended.
Pull your shoulder blades down and together.
Lift your body slightly without bending your arms.
Focus on the shoulder blade movement.

negative-pull-ups.name: Negative Pull-Ups
cues: Jump or use a box to get your chin over the bar.
Lower yourself as slowly as possible (aim for 3-5 seconds).
This builds the eccentric (lowering) strength.
Reset and repeat.

assisted-pull-ups.name: Assisted Pull-Ups
cues: Loop a resistance band around the bar and place your feet in it.
The band provides assistance at the bottom of the movement.
Use a thicker band for more help, a thinner one for less.
Focus on the same pulling mechanics.

chin-ups.name: Chin-Ups
cues: Grip the bar with palms facing you, shoulder-width apart.
Pull up until your chin is over the bar.
Focus on squeezing your biceps at the top.
Lower yourself fully with control.

pull-ups.name: Pull-Ups
cues: Grip the bar with palms facing away, slightly wider than shoulders.
Start from a dead hang with arms fully extended.
Pull your chest towards the bar by driving your elbows down.
Lower yourself with control until arms are straight again.

wide-grip-pull-ups.name: Wide-Grip Pull-Ups
cues: Grip the bar with hands wider than shoulder-width.
Focus on pulling your elbows down and back.
This emphasizes the lats more than regular pull-ups.
Keep your core tight throughout the movement.

l-sit-pull-ups.name: L-Sit Pull-Ups
cues: Hang from the bar and lift your legs to form an L-shape.
Maintain the L-sit position throughout the pull-up.
This adds significant core and hip flexor demand.
One of the most challenging pull-up variations.

muscle-ups.name: Muscle-Ups
cues: Start with an explosive pull-up, getting your chest over the bar.
Transition by leaning forward and pressing down on the bar.
Push yourself up into a dip position above the bar.
Lower with control, reversing the movement.

archer-pull-ups.name: Archer Pull-Ups
cues: Take a wide grip on the bar.
Pull yourself up toward one hand while keeping the other arm straight.
Alternate sides with each rep.
This is a progression toward one-arm pull-ups.

commando-pull-ups.name: Commando Pull-Ups
cues: Grip the bar with hands close together.
Pull yourself up, bringing your head to one side of the bar.
Lower and repeat, alternating sides.
This adds a rotational component to the pull-up.

weighted-pull-ups.name: Weighted Pull-Ups
cues: Add weight using a dip belt or by holding a dumbbell between your feet.
This overloads the muscles for strength and size.
Maintain strict form; don't sacrifice quality for weight.
Start with a light weight and increase gradually.

push-up-family.name: Push-Up Progression Family
push-up-family.description: Complete progression from beginner wall push-ups to advanced one-arm variations

edges.reason: Increases load by using more bodyweight
Transitions to full body plank position
Full bodyweight push-up from floor
Increases load on upper chest and shoulders
Increases tricep activation and reduces base of support
Ultimate single-arm strength and stability challenge

squat-family.name: Squat Progression Family
squat-family.description: Squat progressions from assisted to advanced single-leg variations

edges.reason: Removes depth assistance and builds confidence
Adds explosive power component
Adds external load and improves posture
Single-leg strength and balance challenge

pull-up-family.name: Pull-Up Progression Family
pull-up-family.description: Complete pull-up progression from dead hang to advanced variations

edges.reason: Introduces active shoulder engagement
Builds eccentric strength for full pull-up
Assists full pull-up motion with band support
Full bodyweight pull with supinated grip
Pronated grip increases difficulty
Wider grip emphasizes lats, reduces bicep assistance
Adds significant core and hip flexor demand
Combines pull-up with transition and dip
Unilateral progression toward one-arm pull-up
Adds rotational component and core challenge
Adds external load for strength development
Complementary movement patterns for balanced training
